original: Munimatālakāra nanu yad ukta samvṛtyotpattir iti tatra keya savṛtir nāma /
analyzed: nanu yat ukta samvṛtyā utpattiḥ iti tatra kā iyam savṛtiḥ nāma
translated: But it is said that arising is in terms of concealment, there, what is this so-called concealment?

original: niḥsvabhāveṣv api bhāvato bhāveṣu yā viparītākārādhyāropiṇī bhrāntā buddhiḥ sā savṛtir ucyate /
analyzed: niḥsvabhāveṣu api bhāvataḥ bhāveṣu yā viparīta ākāra adhyāropiṇī bhrāntā buddhiḥ sā sa vṛtiḥ ucyate
translated: It is said that concealment is the deluded cognition that superimposes an opposite form onto things that are actually without intrinsic nature.

original: savriyate cchādyata ivāsyām anayā vā tattvam iti kṛtvā /
analyzed: sa vriyate chādyate iva asyām anayā vā tattvam iti kṛtvā
translated: And it is called concealment because reality is as if concealed by it, or because reality is concealed by it.

original: tathā cokta sūtre bhāvā jāyanti savṛtyā paramārthe niḥsvabhāvakāḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca ukta sūtre bhāvāḥ jāyanti sa vṛtyā paramārthe niḥsvabhāvakāḥ
translated: And it is said in a sutra: Things arise through concealment, in ultimate reality they are without intrinsic nature.

original: niḥsvabhāveṣu yā bhrāntiḥ sā tathyāsavṛtir matā //
analyzed: niḥsvabhāveṣu yā bhrāntiḥ sā matā
translated: The delusion regarding things without intrinsic nature is considered to be the concealment of reality.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: tadbhavatvād vā sarva etadupadarśitā vyalīkā bhāvāḥ sāvṛtā ucyante /
analyzed: tad bhava tvāt vā sarve etad upadarśitāḥ vyalīkāḥ bhāvāḥ sa āvṛtāḥ ucyante
translated: Or, because they exist due to that, all these deceptive things that are shown are said to be concealed.

original: sā cānādivibhramavāsanāparipākavaśād asato bhāvato bhāvān sata ivopadarśayanty upajāyate sarvaprāṇabhṛtā yatas tasmād abhiprāyavaśāt sarva
analyzed: sā ca anādi vibhrama vāsanā paripāka vaśāt asataḥ bhāvataḥ bhāvān sataḥ iva upadarśayantī upajāyate sarva prāṇabhṛtā yatas tasmāt abhiprāya vaśāt sarva
translated: And that arises in all living beings from the ripening of beginningless latent tendencies of error, displaying things as if they existed as real entities when they do not exist. Therefore, from the perspective of intention, all

original: evālīkarūpā bhāvāḥ savṛtisanta ucyante /
analyzed: eva alīka rūpāḥ bhāvāḥ sa vṛti santaḥ ucyante
translated: things that appear as real entities are said to exist through concealment.

original: na punar eṣā bhāvato bhāvarūpatvam /
analyzed: na punar eṣā bhāvataḥ bhāva rūpa tvam
translated: But this does not mean that they exist as real entities.

original: yathāpratibhāsam atattvāt /
analyzed: yathāpratibhāsam atattvāt
translated: Because they are not real as they appear.

original: nāpi śaśaviṣāṇavad atyantābhāvarūpatā /
analyzed: nā api śaśa viṣāṇa vat atyanta abhāva rūpa tā
translated: Nor do they have the nature of absolute non-existence, like the horns of a rabbit.

original: avicāraramaṇīyākāreṇa pratibhāsanāt //
analyzed: avicāra ramaṇīya ākāreṇa pratibhāsanāt
translated: Because it appears in a form delightful to the unreflective.

original: tathā hi māyāpuruṣādau yad bhrāntajñānasamagibhir narair avasthāpita
analyzed: tathā hi māyā puruṣa ādau yat bhrānta jñāna samagibhiḥ naraiḥ
translated: For example, in the case of an illusory man, the form that is established by people who are deluded by magic,

original: rūpam / tadvat sarvapadārtheṣu yad alīkākārajñānasamāropita tat savṛtisatyam iti vyavahriyate /
analyzed: rūpam tadvat sarva padārtheṣu yat tat sa vṛti satyam iti vyavahriyate
translated: in the same way, in all things, the form that is superimposed by false cognition is called conventional truth.

original: tatraiva ca māyāpuruṣādau yathānupaplutavijñānair avasthāpita rūpa tadvat sarvapadārthānā yat samyakpramāṇapariniścita rūpa tat paramārthasatyam
analyzed: tatra eva ca māyā puruṣa ādau yathā anupapluta vijñānaiḥ avasthāpita tadvat sarva padārthānām yat samyak pramāṇa pariniścita tat paramārtha satyam
translated: And in that very illusory man, etc., the form that is established by those whose cognition is not affected, in the same way, in all things, the form that is ascertained by valid cognition is ultimate truth.

original: yathā ca bhrāntābhrāntajñānavyavasthāpitarūpasavṛtiparamā rthasatyadvayāśrayāt taimirikādyupalabhyeṣu keśādiṣu vijñānavādinā ca grāhyagrāhakākāradvaye
analyzed: yathā ca bhrānta abhrānta jñāna vyavasthāpita rūpa sa vṛti paramā artha satya dvaya āśrayāt taimirika ādi upalabhyeṣu keśa ādiṣu vijñāna vādinā ca grāhya grāhaka ākāra dvaye
translated: And just as the two truths, conventional and ultimate, are based on the form established by deluded and undeluded cognition, and the proponent of consciousness distinguishes the difference in the two forms of the grasped and grasper in the hairs, etc. perceived by those with eye disease, etc.,

original: savṛtyā sattva paramārthenāsattvam ityādivyavasthā pekṣābhedān na virudhyate /
analyzed: ityādi vyavasthā pekṣā bhedāt na virudhyate
translated: saying They exist conventionally, but do not exist ultimately, and so on, there is no contradiction.

original: tadvat sarvapadārtheṣu //
analyzed: tadvat sarva padārtheṣu
translated: In the same way, in all things...

original: ato yathoktabhrāntirūpā savṛtir ajanmano'pi bhāvato bhāvān jāyamānān ivopadarśayati yatas tena tadāśrayavaśāt savṛtyotpadyante bhāvā ity
analyzed: atas yathā ukta bhrānti rūpā sa vṛtiḥ ajanmanaḥ api bhāvataḥ bhāvān jāyamānān iva upadarśayati yatas tena tad āśraya vaśāt sa vṛtyā utpadyante bhāvāḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the truth together with the obscurations, which has the form of the error described above, shows even unborn entities as if they were being born. Since they arise from the power of that, entities arise from the truth together with the obscurations.

original: paramārthatas tu notpadyante //
analyzed: paramārthataḥ tu na utpadyante
translated: But in reality, they do not arise.

original: aviparītārthaviṣayatvāt sarvam eva samyakśrutacintābhāvanā maya jñāna paramārtham ucyate /
analyzed: aviparīta artha viṣaya tvāt sarvam eva samyak śruta cintā bhāvanā maya jñāna parama artham ucyate
translated: All knowledge consisting of correct hearing, reflection, and meditation is said to be the truth, because it has as its object the non-erroneous meaning.

original: paramo'syārtha iti kṛtvā //
analyzed: paramaḥ asya arthaḥ iti kṛtvā
translated: Because the highest meaning is its object.

original: sākṣātpāraparyakṛtas tu viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: sākṣāt pāraparya kṛtaḥ tu viśeṣaḥ
translated: But there is a special distinction in direct and indirect ways.

original: tadvaśād ete sarvabhāvā anutpannā eva pratīyante /
analyzed: tad vaśāt ete sarva bhāvāḥ anutpannāḥ eva pratīyante
translated: By its power, all these entities are perceived as unborn.

original: samyagjñānasasiddho naiṣām utpāda ity ukta bhavati //
analyzed: samyak jñāna sa siddhaḥ na eṣām utpādaḥ iti ukta bhavati
translated: It is said that their arising is not established by correct knowledge.

original: avicāro vā savṛtiḥ /🔽tathā hy aviparītatattvanidhyānapravṛttasamyak pramāṇabalabhāvinī cintāmayī prajñā tathā bhāvanāmayy api sākṣāttattvārthānuvicāritayā tanniṣyandatayā
analyzed: a vicāraḥ vā sa vṛtiḥ  tathā hi aviparīta tattva nidhyāna pravṛtta samyak pramāṇa bala bhāvinī cintā mayī prajñā tathā bhāvanā mayī api sākṣāt tattva artha anuvicāri tayā tad nisyanda tayā
translated: Or, the truth together with the obscurations is non-reflection.

original: vā vicāra ucyate /
analyzed: vā vicāraḥ ucyate
translated: For thus, the wisdom consisting of reflection, which arises from the practice of correct means of valid knowledge that is engaged in the meditation on the non-erroneous truth, and likewise the wisdom consisting of meditation, is called reflection because it directly investigates the meaning of the truth or because it is the outflow of that.

original: tathārthaparāṅmukha tu sarvam eva tadviparyayād alīkākāropagrāhi jñānam avicāraḥ /
analyzed: tathā artha parāṅmukha tu sarvam eva tad viparyayāt alīka ākāra upagrāhi jñānam avicāraḥ
translated: And likewise, all knowledge that grasps false forms, turning away from the truth in that way, is non-reflection because it is the opposite of that.

original: na tu nirvikalpaka jñāna nāpi vicārābhāvamātram /
analyzed: na tu nirvikalpaka jñāna na api vicāra abhāva mātram
translated: But not non-conceptual knowledge, nor mere absence of investigation.

original: atas tatprasiddharūpatvāt sarva evālīkarūpo bhāvaḥ sāvṛtaḥ //
analyzed: atas tad prasiddha rūpa tvāt sarvaḥ evā alīka rūpaḥ bhāvaḥ sa āvṛtaḥ
translated: Therefore, because it is of the nature accepted by them, all entities are indeed covered with obscuration.

original: atha vā lokapratītiḥ savṛtiḥ /
analyzed: atha vā loka pratītiḥ sa vṛtiḥ
translated: Or, worldly cognition is with obscuration.

original: sarvalokaprasiddhasya sarvasyaivārthasya sāvṛtatveneṣṭatvāt /
analyzed: sarva loka prasiddhasya sarvasya eva arthasya sa āvṛta tvena iṣṭatvāt
translated: Because all objects, which are well-known to all people, are accepted as being with obscuration.

original: na ca sarvo'rtho'pi sarvasyaivendriyasya gocaraḥ kasyacid eva kaiścid īkṣaṇāt //
analyzed: na ca sarvaḥ ūrthaḥ api sarvasya eva indriyasya gocaraḥ kasyacid eva kaiścid īkṣaṇāt
translated: And not all objects are the domain of all sense faculties, because some are seen by some.

original: ato'tyantaparokṣasya sarvākārapratiniyatakarmaphalāder vyavasthā sarvajñajñānata evānyasya punar itarajñānato'pi //
analyzed: atas utyanta parokṣasya sarva ākāra pratiniyata karma phala ādeḥ vyavasthā sarvajña jñānataḥ eva anyasya punar itara jñānataḥ api
translated: Therefore, the determination of what is absolutely imperceptible, such as the results of actions that are restricted in all aspects, is only from the knowledge of the Omniscient One. For others, it is from other knowledge as well.

original: yat punaḥ kaiścic chāstrakāraiḥ pratītim ullaghya bhāvānā nityādirūpam upakalpita tat mithyāsavṛtisad ucyate /
analyzed: yat punar kaiścid śāstra kāraiḥ pratītim ullaghya bhāvānām nitya ādi rūpam tat mithyā savṛti sat ucyate
translated: But that which is imagined by some authors of treatises to be the form of permanent entities, etc., in contradiction to cognition, is said to be false with obscuration.

original: pratītito'pi tasyāsattvāt /
analyzed: pratītitaḥ api tasya asattvāt
translated: Because it does not exist even from the point of view of cognition.

original: yat punaḥ pratītyanusārataḥ prakalpitam /
analyzed: yat punar pratīti anusārataḥ prakalpitam
translated: But that which is imagined in accordance with cognition,

original: yathā nāstīha sattva ātmā ca dharmās tv ete sahetukā iti /
analyzed: yathā na asti iha sattvaḥ ātmā ca dharmāḥ tu ete sa hetukāḥ iti
translated: such as Here there is no being or self, but these phenomena have causes,

original: tat tathyasavṛtisad ucyate /
analyzed: tat tathya savṛti sad ucyate
translated: that is said to be true with obscuration.

original: tena saty apy ekatra vastuni śāstrakārāṇām anekarūpavyārope vastuno na pa rasparaviruddhānekasvabhāvatāprasaṅgaḥ //
analyzed: tena sati api ekatra vastuni śāstra kārāṇām aneka rūpa vyārope vastunaḥ na paraspara viruddha aneka svabhāva tā prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Therefore, even though the authors of treatises superimpose many forms on one thing, it does not follow that the thing has many mutually contradictory natures.

original: māyārtho vā savṛtyarthaḥ /
analyzed: māyā arthaḥ vā sa vṛti arthaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning of 'with superimposition' is the meaning of 'illusion'.

original: asatyārtho māyārthaḥ /
analyzed: asatya arthaḥ māyā arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of 'illusion' is the meaning of 'untruth'.

original: bhrāntajñānarūpe 'pi ca māyārthe jñānasya na vastutāprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: bhrānta jñāna rūpe ca māyā arthe jñānasya na vastu tā prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And even in an illusory object that is the form of deluded cognition, it does not follow that cognition has the nature of an entity.

original: alīkākāropagraheṇa tasya bhāsanāt /
analyzed: alīka ākāra upagraheṇa tasya bhāsanāt
translated: Because it appears through apprehending a false form.

original: satyālīkarūpayoś ca parasparaviruddhatvāt /
analyzed: satya alīka rūpayoḥ ca paraspara viruddha tvāt
translated: And because true and false forms are mutually contradictory.

original: tenālīkarūpatāyā api satyatāpatter na bhrāntatā jñānasya bhāvet /
analyzed: tena alīka rūpa tāyāḥ api satya tā āpatteḥ na bhrānta tā jñānasya
translated: Therefore, even if it has a false form, the cognition would not be deluded, because it would follow that the false form is also true.

original: nāpi citrarūpatā virodhāt //
analyzed: na api citra rūpa tā virodhāt
translated: And it would not have a variegated form, because of contradiction.

original: bhrāntatve vāsatyarūpatāyā apy alīkatvān na jñānasya satyatā bhavet /
analyzed: bhrānta tve vā asatya rūpa tāyāḥ api alīka tvāt na jñānasya satya tā bhavet
translated: If it were deluded, then because even the false form would be unreal, the cognition would not be true.

original: sarvātmanā tayoḥ parasparam anānātvād ekasyāṅgāṅgibhāvāsabhavāt /
analyzed: sarva ātmanā tayoḥ parasparam anānātvāt ekasya aṅgāṅgibhāva asabhavāt
translated: Because in every way they are not different from each other, and one cannot be the subordinate and the other the principal.

original: ato jñānasyāpy alīkatvād antarjñeyanayād asya mahān viśeṣaḥ //
analyzed: atas jñānasya api alīka tvāt antar jñeya nayāt asya mahān viśeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, because the cognition is also unreal, there is a great difference between this [view] and the doctrine of internal objects.

original: śabda mātra savṛtir ity anabhijñāḥ /
analyzed: śabda mātra sa vṛtiḥ iti anabhijñāḥ
translated: The ignorant say that 'with superimposition' means 'with mere words'.

original: na hi śabdamātra savṛtir iti kasyāpi saugatasya matam /
analyzed: na hi śabda mātra sa vṛtiḥ iti kasya api saugatasya matam
translated: For no Buddhist holds the view that 'with superimposition' means 'with mere words'.

original: yad api nāmamātram ida sarva sajñāmātre pratiṣṭhitam /
analyzed: yat api nāma mātram idam sarva sajñā mātre pratiṣṭhitam
translated: And also, this whole [world] is merely names, established in mere concepts.

original: abhidhānāt pṛthagbhūtam abhidheya na vidyate //
analyzed: abhidhānāt pṛthak bhūtam abhidheya na vidyate
translated: Apart from the designation, the designated object does not exist.

original: iti sūtre'bhihitam /
analyzed: iti sūtre abhihitam
translated: Thus it is stated in the sutra.

original: tatrāpi ye vastubhūtam evābhidhānam abhidheya ca tatpṛthagbhūtam api kalpayanti tanmatapratiṣedhāya kalpanāpratiṣṭhitatvam evābhidhānābhidheyayor
analyzed: tatra api ye vastu bhūtam eva abhidhānam ca tat pṛthak bhūtam api kalpayanti tad mata pratiṣedhāya kalpanā pratiṣṭhita tvam eva abhidhāna abhidheyayoḥ
translated: Even there, for those who imagine the designation and the designated object to be truly existent and separate, the non-establishment in conceptualization is shown regarding the designation and the designated object.

original: upadarśitam /
analyzed: upadarśitam
translated: In order to refute that view.

original: sajñā hy atra kalpanā /
analyzed: sajñā hi atra kalpanā
translated: For here, conceptualization is a concept.

original: kalpanārūpam evābhidhāna nāmaśabdenābhipretam /
analyzed: kalpanā rūpam
translated: The form of conceptualization is what is meant by the word name in the designation.

original: na tu śrotrajñānapratibhāsy arthasyāvācakatvāt /
analyzed: na tu śrotra jñāna pratibhāsi arthasya avācaka tvāt
translated: But it is not the object that appears in the cognition of the ear, because it does not express that.

original: tanmātratve ca viśvasya rūpādivaicitryapratibhāso na bhavet /
analyzed: tanmātra tve ca viśvasya rūpa ādi vaicitrya pratibhāsaḥ na bhavet
translated: And if it were merely that, the appearance of the variety of forms and so on would not occur.

original: nāpi skandhādivya vasthā //
analyzed: nā api skandha ādi vya vasthā
translated: Nor would the classification into aggregates and so on.

original: yathā ca bahuṣu māyānareṣu naro nara iti sāmānyākārarūpaḥ kalpitaḥ śabdārtho vyavasthāpyate /
analyzed: yathā ca bahuṣu māyā nareṣu naraḥ naraḥ iti sāmānya ākāra rūpaḥ kalpitaḥ śabda arthaḥ vyavasthāpyate
translated: And just as a man is established as the general form of the word man in many illusory men,

original: tathā paramārthāsvabhāveṣv api bhāveṣu paramārtho'py adhyāropitarūpeṇa kathyamānaḥ savṛtir eva bhavet /
analyzed: tathā paramārtha asvabhāveṣu api bhāveṣu paramārthaḥ api adhyāropita rūpeṇa kathyamānaḥ sa vṛtiḥ eva bhavet
translated: in the same way, even in things that are ultimately natureless, the ultimate, though superimposed in the form of an appearance, would be only with a covering.

original: tasya sarvaprapañcātikrāntatvāt /
analyzed: tasya sarva prapañca atikrānta tvāt
translated: Because it transcends all conceptual proliferation.

original: tathā cokta sūtre yadi devaputra paramārthataḥ paramārthasatya kāyavāṅmanasā viṣayabhāvam āgacchen na paramārthasatyam iti sakhyā gacchet
analyzed: tathā ca ukta sūtre yadi devaputra paramārthataḥ paramārtha satya kāya vāc manasā viṣaya bhāvam āgacchet na paramārtha satyam iti sakhyā gacchet  /
translated: And thus it is said in the sutra: If, O son of the gods, the ultimate truth were to come within the sphere of action of body, speech, or mind in the ultimate sense, it would not be called the ultimate truth.

original: savṛtisatyam eva tad bhavet /
analyzed: sa vṛti satyam eva tat bhavet
translated: It would be merely conventional truth.

original: api tu paramārthataḥ paramārthasatya sarvavyavahārātikrāntam /
analyzed: api tu paramārthataḥ paramārtha satya sarva vyavahāra atikrāntam
translated: But the ultimate truth transcends all conventional usage in the ultimate sense.

original: iti //
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus it is.

original: kṣaṇikatva vā bhāvānā savṛtiḥ /
analyzed: kṣaṇika tva vā bhāvānā savṛtiḥ
translated: Or, the conventional is in terms of the momentariness of things.

original: teṣā calātmanā sarvabhāvānā yā māyāvat prakṛtiniḥsvabhāvatālakṣaṇā śūnyatā sa paramārthaḥ /
analyzed: teṣām cala ātmanā sarva bhāvānām yā māyā vat prakṛti niḥsvabhāva tā lakṣaṇā śūnyatā sa paramārthaḥ
translated: That emptiness which is the characteristic of the nature of all things being devoid of self-existence like an illusion is the ultimate.

original: sarvatathāgatānām utpādānutpādayor api sarvakālam adhiṣṭhitatvān nityaḥ //
analyzed: sarva tathāgatānām utpāda anutpādayoḥ api sarvakālam adhiṣṭhita tvāt nityaḥ
translated: It is eternal because it is always present, even in the production and non-production of all Tathagatas.
